questions.question: A cash-method taxpayer expecting lower tax rates next year can defer income by:

options.B: Delaying billing until January
options.C: Depositing December checks in January
options.D: Backdating invoices to the prior year

questions.explanation: Cash-method taxpayers recognize income when received. Delaying billing pushes receipt of payment into the next year, deferring income recognition. Depositing checks later doesn't help - constructive receipt occurs when payment is available. Backdating invoices is fraudulent and doesn't affect cash basis recognition.
questions.tip: Cash basis income planning: control when you BILL, not when you deposit. Constructive receipt matters.

questions.question: The strategy of 'bunching' itemized deductions involves:

options.B: Concentrating deductible expenses in alternate years
options.C: Converting itemized deductions to business deductions
options.D: Claiming the standard deduction every year

questions.explanation: Bunching involves concentrating itemized deductions (like charitable contributions) into alternate years to exceed the standard deduction in those years, then taking the standard deduction in the other years. This maximizes total deductions compared to spreading expenses evenly when the standard deduction is high.
questions.tip: Bunching = alternate year strategy. High itemized year → itemize; low year → standard deduction.

questions.question: Interest from municipal bonds is generally:

options.B: Taxed at capital gains rates
options.C: Exempt from federal income tax
options.D: Deferred until maturity

questions.explanation: Interest from municipal bonds (issued by state and local governments) is generally exempt from federal income tax. It may also be exempt from state tax if issued by the taxpayer's home state. However, some municipal bond interest (private activity bonds) may be a preference item for AMT purposes.
questions.tip: Muni bond interest = federally tax-exempt. Compare tax-equivalent yield to taxable bonds.

questions.question: To qualify for long-term capital gain rates, an asset must be held for:

options.B: More than 12 months
options.C: At least 18 months
options.D: More than 24 months

questions.explanation: Long-term capital gain treatment requires a holding period of more than one year (12 months). If sold on the one-year anniversary, the gain is still short-term. Holding one day beyond the one-year anniversary qualifies for the preferential 0%/15%/20% rates instead of ordinary income rates.
questions.tip: LTCG = held MORE than 12 months. Sale on exact anniversary = short-term.

questions.question: A taxpayer expecting to be in a higher tax bracket during retirement would generally benefit most from:

options.B: Roth IRA contributions
options.C: Non-deductible traditional IRA contributions
options.D: Neither type of IRA

questions.explanation: Roth IRA contributions are made with after-tax dollars, and qualified distributions are tax-free. If a taxpayer expects higher rates in retirement, paying tax now at lower rates (Roth) is preferable to deferring tax (Traditional IRA) only to pay at higher rates later.
questions.tip: Roth = pay tax now (good if rates rise). Traditional = pay tax later (good if rates drop). Consider future brackets.

questions.question: The kiddie tax can be avoided by investing a child's funds in:

options.B: Dividend-paying stocks
options.C: Growth stocks that do not pay dividends
options.D: Money market funds

questions.explanation: The kiddie tax applies to unearned income (interest, dividends, capital gains) above a threshold. Growth stocks that don't pay dividends produce no current income and thus avoid kiddie tax. The gain is deferred until sale, potentially when the child is no longer subject to kiddie tax rules.
questions.tip: Kiddie tax planning: use growth stocks or Series EE/I bonds to defer income until child is older.

questions.question: A cash-method taxpayer receives a check on December 30 but does not deposit it until January 3. The income is taxable in:

options.B: December of the current year
options.C: The year the taxpayer chooses
options.D: Equally between both years

questions.explanation: Under constructive receipt doctrine, income is taxable when it is made available to the taxpayer without substantial limitations, not when actually received. A check received December 30 is constructively received then, even if deposited later. The taxpayer cannot defer income by delaying deposit.
questions.tip: Constructive receipt = income available without restriction. Can't delay by not depositing a check you received.

questions.question: The key tax difference between incentive stock options (ISOs) and nonqualified stock options (NSOs) at exercise is that:

options.A: ISOs create ordinary income at exercise; NSOs do not
options.B: NSOs create ordinary income at exercise; ISOs generally do not for regular tax
options.C: Both create capital gain at exercise
options.D: Neither creates any tax consequence at exercise

questions.explanation: At exercise, NSOs create ordinary income equal to the spread (FMV minus exercise price). ISOs generally do not create regular tax income at exercise (but do create an AMT preference item). ISO holders recognize gain at sale, potentially qualifying for capital gain treatment if holding requirements are met.
questions.tip: ISO = no regular tax at exercise (but AMT preference). NSO = ordinary income at exercise.

questions.question: Tax loss harvesting involves:

options.B: Selling investments at a loss to offset gains
options.C: Converting short-term losses to long-term losses
options.D: Donating loss positions to charity

questions.explanation: Tax loss harvesting is the strategy of selling investments at a loss to realize capital losses that offset capital gains and up to $3,000 of ordinary income annually. Taxpayers often reinvest in similar (but not substantially identical) securities to maintain market exposure while realizing the tax benefit.
questions.tip: Loss harvesting: sell to realize loss, reinvest in similar (not identical) security. Watch wash sale rules!

questions.question: The 3.8% net investment income tax (NIIT) applies to individuals with modified AGI exceeding:

options.B: $200,000 for single filers, $250,000 for married filing jointly
options.C: $250,000 for all filers
options.D: $400,000 for single filers, $450,000 for married filing jointly

questions.explanation: The NIIT applies to the lesser of net investment income or MAGI exceeding threshold amounts: $250,000 (MFJ), $200,000 (single/HoH), $125,000 (MFS). Net investment income includes interest, dividends, capital gains, and passive income, but not wages or active business income.
questions.tip: NIIT = 3.8% on investment income. Thresholds: $200K single, $250K MFJ, $125K MFS. Not indexed for inflation!

questions.question: Using an installment sale to sell appreciated property provides tax benefits by:

options.A: Converting ordinary income to capital gain
options.B: Eliminating gain recognition entirely
options.C: Deferring gain recognition as payments are received
options.D: Allowing stepped-up basis for the buyer

questions.explanation: Installment sales allow sellers to spread gain recognition over the period payments are received, rather than recognizing all gain in the year of sale. This provides deferral benefits and may keep the seller in lower tax brackets each year. However, depreciation recapture is recognized in year of sale.
questions.tip: Installment sale = defer gain to when payments received. Exception: depreciation recapture recognized in year 1.

questions.question: For 2024, the maximum employee elective deferral to a 401(k) plan for an employee under age 50 is:
questions.explanation: For 2024, the employee elective deferral limit for 401(k) plans is $23,000 (indexed for inflation). Those age 50 and over can contribute an additional $7,500 catch-up. The $69,000 is the total annual addition limit (employee + employer contributions).
questions.tip: 2024 401(k): $23,000 employee limit + $7,500 catch-up if 50+. Total additions capped at $69,000.

questions.question: Donating long-term appreciated stock to a public charity instead of selling and donating cash provides what tax advantage?

options.B: Avoidance of capital gains tax on the appreciation
options.C: Deduction for twice the fair market value
options.D: Conversion of ordinary income to capital gain

questions.explanation: Donating appreciated stock held long-term provides a deduction for fair market value while avoiding recognition of the built-in capital gain. If the stock were sold first, the taxpayer would owe capital gains tax, reducing the amount available for charity. The deduction is the same (FMV) either way.
questions.tip: Donate appreciated stock, don't sell first. Avoid cap gains tax and get FMV deduction.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to trigger alternative minimum tax (AMT)?

options.B: Exercise of incentive stock options with large spread
options.C: Significant charitable contributions
options.D: High qualified dividend income

questions.explanation: Exercising ISOs creates an AMT adjustment equal to the spread (FMV minus exercise price). This is one of the most common AMT triggers. Acquisition debt interest, charitable contributions, and qualified dividends are generally not AMT preference items.
questions.tip: ISO exercise = major AMT trigger. Plan ISO exercises to avoid or minimize AMT.

questions.question: A specified service trade or business (SSTB) is subject to QBI deduction limitations. Which of the following is NOT an SSTB?

options.B: Medical practice
options.C: Architecture firm
options.D: Consulting business

questions.explanation: Architecture and engineering are specifically excluded from the definition of specified service trades or businesses (SSTBs). Law, health, accounting, actuarial science, performing arts, consulting, athletics, financial services, and brokerage services are all SSTBs subject to income-based QBI limitations.
questions.tip: Architecture and engineering are NOT SSTBs - they get full QBI benefit regardless of income.

questions.question: Under the cash method, prepaid expenses are generally deductible:

options.A: When paid, regardless of the benefit period
options.B: Ratably over the period to which they relate
options.C: In the earlier of when paid or when economic performance occurs
options.D: Only in the year the benefit is received

questions.explanation: Even for cash-method taxpayers, prepaid expenses extending beyond 12 months beyond the end of the current tax year must be capitalized and deducted over the benefit period. The 12-month rule allows current deduction if the benefit doesn't extend more than 12 months after payment.
questions.tip: 12-month rule: prepaid expense deductible if benefit doesn't extend beyond 12 months from payment date.

questions.question: The net unrealized appreciation (NUA) strategy for employer stock in a 401(k) involves:

options.A: Rolling over all assets to an IRA
options.B: Taking a lump-sum distribution with stock distributed in-kind
options.C: Converting the 401(k) to a Roth IRA
options.D: Donating the stock to charity from the 401(k)

questions.explanation: NUA strategy involves taking a lump-sum distribution from the 401(k) with employer stock distributed in-kind rather than sold. Only the cost basis is taxed as ordinary income at distribution. The NUA (appreciation) is taxed as long-term capital gain when the stock is later sold.
questions.tip: NUA = get LTCG treatment on employer stock appreciation instead of ordinary income. Requires in-kind distribution.

questions.question: Which type of property is NOT eligible for installment sale reporting?

options.A: Real property used in a trade or business
options.B: Personal residence
options.C: Publicly traded securities
options.D: Rental property

questions.explanation: Publicly traded securities cannot use installment sale reporting because there's a readily available market for immediate sale. Other ineligible property includes inventory and dealer sales. Real property (business use, residence, rental) generally qualifies for installment sale treatment.
questions.tip: Installment sales not available for: inventory, dealer property, publicly traded securities.

questions.question: The assignment of income doctrine prevents:

options.A: Gifts of property to family members
options.B: Shifting earned income by directing payment to another person
options.C: Employing family members at fair market wages
options.D: Transferring dividend-paying stock to children

questions.explanation: The assignment of income doctrine prevents taxpayers from avoiding tax by directing earned income to another person. The person who earns income must report it. However, transferring income-producing property (shifting the 'tree' not just the 'fruit') is permitted, as is paying reasonable wages to family employees.
questions.tip: Assignment of income: can't assign fruit, but can gift the tree. Transfer property, not just income.

questions.question: Capital gains invested in a Qualified Opportunity Zone Fund receive which tax benefit?

options.A: Immediate exclusion of the original gain
options.B: Deferral of the original gain and potential exclusion of future appreciation
options.C: Conversion of short-term gain to long-term gain
options.D: 100% exclusion of all gains

questions.explanation: Investing capital gains in a QOZ Fund provides: (1) deferral of the original gain until December 31, 2026, or earlier disposition, and (2) exclusion of appreciation on the QOZ investment if held at least 10 years. The original gain step-up benefits expired after 2021.
questions.tip: QOZ: defer gain until 2026, exclude appreciation after 10-year hold. Original gain step-up benefits expired.

questions.question: For dividends to qualify for preferential tax rates, the stock must be held for more than:

options.A: 30 days during the 61-day period around the ex-dividend date
options.B: 60 days during the 121-day period around the ex-dividend date
options.C: 90 days before the ex-dividend date
options.D: 120 days after the dividend payment date

questions.explanation: For common stock dividends to qualify for the preferential 0%/15%/20% rates, the stock must be held for more than 60 days during the 121-day period beginning 60 days before the ex-dividend date. Preferred stock has a 91-day requirement during a 181-day window for dividends on periods over 366 days.
questions.tip: Qualified dividend holding period: >60 days in 121-day window around ex-dividend date.

questions.question: A strategy to reduce future required minimum distributions (RMDs) includes:

options.B: Converting traditional IRA assets to Roth IRA
options.C: Delaying retirement
options.D: Increasing current withdrawals

questions.explanation: Roth IRAs do not have RMDs during the owner's lifetime. Converting traditional IRA assets to Roth (paying tax now) reduces future RMDs by removing those assets from accounts subject to RMD rules. This is especially valuable in lower income years when conversion tax cost is reduced.
questions.tip: Roth conversion reduces RMDs - no lifetime RMDs for Roth IRAs. Convert in low-income years.

questions.question: A donor advised fund (DAF) provides flexibility in charitable giving because:

options.A: Contributions are deductible when grants are made to charities
options.B: The contribution is deductible immediately while grants can be made in future years
options.C: Contributions can be revoked if the donor changes their mind
options.D: The fund can make grants to individuals

questions.explanation: DAFs provide immediate charitable deduction when the contribution is made, while allowing the donor to recommend grants to specific charities over time. This separates the tax benefit timing from the charitable disbursement timing. Contributions are irrevocable, and grants must go to qualified charities, not individuals.
questions.tip: DAF = deduction now, grant later. Great for bunching in high-income years with gradual distributions.

questions.question: A Section 83(b) election is beneficial when:

options.A: The restricted property is expected to decrease in value
options.B: The taxpayer wants to defer income recognition
options.C: The restricted property is expected to substantially appreciate
options.D: The taxpayer expects to forfeit the property

questions.explanation: Section 83(b) allows taxpayers to elect to include restricted property in income at grant (when value is typically low) rather than at vesting (when value may be higher). If property appreciates substantially, all appreciation after the 83(b) election is taxed as capital gain. If property decreases in value or is forfeited, the election cannot be reversed.
questions.tip: 83(b) election = pay tax now at low value, get capital gain on future appreciation. Must file within 30 days!

questions.question: Section 1202 qualified small business stock (QSBS) exclusion allows taxpayers to exclude from gross income up to:

options.B: 75% of gain, capped at $10 million
options.C: 100% of gain, subject to limitations
options.D: $250,000 of gain per taxpayer

questions.explanation: For QSBS acquired after September 27, 2010, Section 1202 allows 100% exclusion of gain, limited to the greater of $10 million or 10 times the adjusted basis of QSBS in that corporation. The stock must be held more than 5 years and meet other requirements (C corp, active business, under $50M gross assets).
questions.tip: QSBS = up to 100% exclusion, max of $10M or 10x basis. Must hold 5+ years, C corp, active business.

questions.question: AMT paid due to timing differences (deferral items) generates:

options.B: A minimum tax credit usable in future years
options.C: An ordinary loss deduction
options.D: A reduction in future AMT exemption

questions.explanation: AMT paid due to deferral preferences (like ISO exercises or MACRS vs. AMT depreciation) generates a minimum tax credit (MTC) that can offset regular tax in future years. Exclusion items (like private activity bond interest) do not generate MTC. The credit helps equalize taxation over time.
questions.tip: Deferral AMT items → MTC credit for future regular tax offset. Exclusion items → no credit.

questions.question: The 'backdoor Roth' strategy involves:

options.B: Making non-deductible traditional IRA contributions and converting to Roth
options.C: Withdrawing from a 401(k) to fund a Roth IRA
options.D: Borrowing from a Roth IRA

questions.explanation: The backdoor Roth strategy allows high-income taxpayers who exceed Roth IRA income limits to make non-deductible traditional IRA contributions and then convert to Roth. The pro-rata rule may cause partial taxation if the taxpayer has other pre-tax IRA balances. This remains a legal strategy after Build Back Better failed to eliminate it.
questions.tip: Backdoor Roth: nondeductible traditional IRA → convert to Roth. Beware pro-rata rule if you have pre-tax IRAs.

questions.question: Under current law, a child's unearned income subject to the kiddie tax is taxed at:

options.B: The parent's marginal rate
options.C: A flat 15% rate
options.D: The estate and trust tax rates

questions.explanation: Under current law (post-TCJA correction), a child's unearned income subject to the kiddie tax is taxed at the parents' marginal rate. The first threshold amount (indexed, approximately $1,300) is tax-free, the second threshold amount is taxed at the child's rate, and amounts above that are taxed at the parents' marginal rate.
questions.tip: Kiddie tax = parent's rate (current law). Brief use of trust rates was repealed retroactively.

questions.question: A charitable remainder annuity trust (CRAT) provides:

options.A: Variable payments based on trust value each year
options.B: Fixed annual payments regardless of trust value
options.C: All income to charity with remainder to individuals
options.D: No income tax deduction at creation

questions.explanation: A CRAT pays a fixed annuity amount (at least 5% of initial fair market value) to the non-charitable beneficiary for a term or life, with the remainder going to charity. A charitable remainder unitrust (CRUT), in contrast, pays a percentage of trust value determined annually. Both provide income tax deductions at creation.
questions.tip: CRAT = fixed payment. CRUT = variable payment based on annual value. Both give upfront deductions.

questions.question: The wash sale rule applies to repurchases of substantially identical securities within:

options.B: 30 days before the sale only
options.C: 30 days before or after the sale (61-day total period)
options.D: 60 days before or after the sale (121-day total period)

questions.explanation: The wash sale rule disallows a loss if substantially identical securities are purchased within 30 days before or 30 days after the sale, creating a 61-day window (30 days before + sale day + 30 days after). The disallowed loss is added to the basis of the replacement shares.
questions.tip: Wash sale = 61-day window total (30 before + day of sale + 30 after). Loss adds to replacement basis.

questions.question: In a deferred Section 1031 exchange, replacement property must be identified within:

options.B: 45 days of the sale
options.C: 90 days of the sale
options.D: 180 days of the sale

questions.explanation: In a deferred 1031 exchange, replacement property must be identified in writing within 45 days of transferring the relinquished property. The exchange must be completed within 180 days (or the due date of the tax return, if earlier). The 45-day and 180-day periods run concurrently.
questions.tip: 1031 timing: 45 days to identify, 180 days to close. Both periods start on sale of relinquished property.

questions.question: The 'mega backdoor Roth' strategy involves:

options.A: Contributing the maximum to a traditional IRA and converting
options.B: Making after-tax 401(k) contributions and converting to Roth
options.C: Contributing to multiple Roth IRAs
options.D: Using SEP IRA contributions for Roth conversions

questions.explanation: The mega backdoor Roth allows employees whose 401(k) plans permit after-tax contributions (beyond the regular elective deferral limit) to contribute and then convert those after-tax funds to Roth (in-plan or via rollover). This can add up to approximately $46,000 of additional Roth contributions in 2024.
questions.tip: Mega backdoor = after-tax 401(k) contributions → Roth. Plan must allow after-tax and in-service distributions.

questions.question: Section 1045 allows deferral of gain on QSBS by:

options.A: Investing in any qualified opportunity zone
options.B: Rolling gain into replacement QSBS within 60 days
options.C: Converting QSBS to S corporation stock
options.D: Donating QSBS to a charitable remainder trust

questions.explanation: Section 1045 allows non-corporate taxpayers to roll over gain from the sale of QSBS held more than 6 months by purchasing replacement QSBS within 60 days. The gain is deferred and reduces the basis of the replacement stock. This can be combined with Section 1202 exclusion for the replacement stock.
questions.tip: Section 1045 rollover: sell QSBS (held 6+ months) → reinvest in new QSBS within 60 days → defer gain.

questions.question: For taxpayers above the QBI income threshold, the deduction is limited to the greater of:

options.A: 50% of QBI or 20% of W-2 wages
options.B: 50% of W-2 wages or 25% of W-2 wages plus 2.5% of UBIA
options.C: 25% of QBI or 50% of W-2 wages
options.D: 20% of QBI or 50% of W-2 wages plus 25% of UBIA

questions.explanation: For non-SSTB businesses, taxpayers above the income threshold face a limitation: QBI deduction cannot exceed the greater of (1) 50% of W-2 wages, or (2) 25% of W-2 wages plus 2.5% of the unadjusted basis immediately after acquisition (UBIA) of qualified property.
questions.tip: QBI cap = greater of: (1) 50% W-2 wages, or (2) 25% wages + 2.5% UBIA. Both limits phase in above threshold.

questions.question: A qualified charitable distribution (QCD) from an IRA allows taxpayers age 70½ or older to:

options.A: Deduct contributions above the 60% AGI limit
options.B: Transfer up to $105,000 annually directly to charity, satisfying RMDs without increasing AGI
options.C: Convert to Roth IRA without taxation
options.D: Avoid the 10% early withdrawal penalty on any distribution

questions.explanation: QCDs allow taxpayers 70½ or older to transfer up to $105,000 (2024, indexed) directly from an IRA to qualified charities. The distribution satisfies RMD requirements but isn't included in gross income. This benefits taxpayers who don't itemize or want to reduce AGI for other phase-outs.
questions.tip: QCD = direct IRA-to-charity transfer. Satisfies RMD, doesn't increase AGI, doesn't require itemizing.
